docs.title: Welcome to MkDocs
docs.text: For full documentation visit mkdocs.org.

docs.title: Commands
docs.text:
• mkdocs new [dir-name] - Create a new project.
  • mkdocs serve - Start the live-reloading docs server.
  • mkdocs build - Build the documentation site.
  • mkdocs -h - Print help message and exit.

docs.title: Project layout
docs.text:
mkdocs.yml    # The configuration file.
docs/
    index.md  # The documentation homepage.
    ...       # Other markdown pages, images and other files. fig

docs.title: Resources
docs.text: • WCP Hardware Documentation

docs.title: Screws
docs.text:
• We use primarily 10-32 screws for structural applications
  • We sometimes use 8-32 screws for mounting non-structural items, like electronics
  • 1/4-20 screws can be used if there are very high loads on a single screw
  • We sometimes use smaller screws, 4-40 and 6-32, for mounting very small electrical components

docs.title: Rivets
docs.text:
• 3/16 high strength aluminum rivets can be used for structural applications like drivetrain and superstructure
  • 3/16 and 5/32 aluminum rivets can be used for creating light and rigid subassemblies
  • Rivets should NEVER be used for assemblies that will need to be disassembled for access or maintenance

docs.title: Resources
docs.text:
• WCP Fasteners Documentation.
  • Chief Delphi Citrus Circuits Rivet Use
  • Chief Delphi Rivet Thread

docs.title: Motors
docs.text: Our team uses the CTRE Phoenix 6 API for programming, which is compatible with motors and controllers sold by CTRE and West Coast Products. We primarily use Kraken X60 and Kraken X44 brushless motors, which have an integrated TalonFX controller.

docs.title: Kraken X60
docs.text:
The Kraken X60 is the largest brushless motor sold by West Coast Products. It has an integrated TalonFX controller.

Primary Applications:

  • Swerve module drive motor
  • Swerve Module steering motor
  • High inertia linear motion, e.g. elevator
  • High inertia rotational motion, e.g. arm pivot
  • Shooter flywheel motors

Links:

  • Kraken X60 - WCP Store Page
  • Kraken X60 - WCP Documentation

docs.title: Kraken X44
docs.text:
The Kraken X44 is a smaller version of the X60.

Primary Applications:

  • Swerve module steering motor
  • driving wheels or rollers for intakes, indexing, etc.
  • Low inertia or low speed motion

Links:

  • Kraken X44 - WCP Store Page
  • Kraken X60 - WCP Documentation

docs.title: CTR Minion
docs.text:
The CTR Minion is the smallest and lightest motor we use. It does not have an integrated controller, and the outer housing of the motor spins with the shaft, making it vulnerable to impacts from game pieces or other parts of the robot.

Primary Applications:

  • Same as Kraken X44
  • Only use the minion when extremely space or weight constrained, or we are out of x44 motors

Links:

  • CTRE Minion - WCP Store Page
  • CTRE Minion - CTRE Store Page

docs.title: 775 Pro
docs.text:
The 775 Pro is a brushed motor which uses an external Talon SRX controller. We have a lot of them, and they are compatible with the versa planetary gearbox.

Primary Applications:

  • Prototyping

Link:

  • 775 Pro - West Coast Products

docs.title: Resources
docs.text: • WCP Hardware Documentation

docs.title: Swerve
docs.text: We currently use the swerve drive specialties mk4i and mk4n swerve modules, with two Kraken X60 motors per module for drive and steering.

docs.title: Resources
docs.text: • SDS Store

docs.title: Laguna CNC Router
docs.text:
• 24"x36" work area
  • Vacuum table for holding down large flat stock
  • Tube cutting jig for rectangular and square aluminum tubing

docs.title: Blue Prolight Bench-top Mills
docs.text:
• 6"x11" work area
  • Used for smaller thicker parts with more 3d geometry

docs.title: CNC Lathe
docs.text: • Used for spacers, standoffs and axles

docs.title: Drill Press
docs.text:
• RPM adjustable with belts in top cover, depending on material and bit size
  • Used to create or enlarge holes

docs.title: Band Saw
docs.text: • Used to make rough cuts in plastic, wood and aluminum

docs.title: Miter Saw
docs.text: • Used to cut long wood, plastic or aluminum stock to length

docs.title: Manual Lathe
docs.text: • Used for making spacers, axels and standoffs

docs.title: Block CAD
docs.text: We use the high fidelity block CAD setup described in the linked youtube video and chief delphi thread.

docs.title: Document Structure
docs.text:
We use the following document structure for our build season CAD in Onshape:

  • Top Level Document contains:

    • Master Sketches
    • High Fidelity Block CAD
    • Block CAD Assembly
    • Main Robot Assembly

  • Sub-assembly Documents, each contain:

    • Detailed sub-assembly part studio, possibly multiple depending on complexity
    • Detailed sub-assembly assembly file

docs.title: Intro to Onshape
docs.text: Please follow the steps at the frcdesign.org learning course to get started with Onshape. Message Sam Weston or Kevin Hjelstrom on slack to get added to the team Onshape classroom.

docs.title: Versioning Best Practices
docs.text:
The Onshape version tracking system for a document can be accessed through this tab on the left side of the page.

A version is like a milestone in your design. Create a version if you reach a place you'd like to be able to get back to easily, for example if you are about to make drastic changes that may break geometry. A version must also be created in order to create a branch, which we will talk about next. To create a version, click this tab on the upper left of the page.

A branch is a separate design workspace that is maintained in parallel with the main branch. It allows you to try out designs or modify design aspects without effecting others who are working on other aspects of the same document.

Merging one branch into another means copying any updates from the merging branch into the active branch. You can merge changes from the main branch to update the space you're working on with other people's changes, and when your changes are ready, you can merge them into the main branch to share your updates with everyone else.

To create a new branch, right click the version you want to branch from in the versions and history tree, and select "Branch to create workspace...".

To merge a branch, click the branch you want to merge into to open its workspace, then right click on the branch you want to merge into it, and select "merge into current branch".
